thread.title: Yale launches amazing database of Depression-era Oregon photos (PHOTOS)
thread.title_full: Yale launches amazing database of Depression-era Oregon photos (PHOTOS) | OregonLive.com

author: Joseph Rose | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: Yale launches amazing database of Depression-era Oregon photos (PHOTOS)
text:
One more reason for history buffs to love the Internet: Yale University has developed an amazing navigable map that allows the public to search 170,000 of the U.S. government's Great Depression-era photos by geography.
Using the Yale-developed interactive browsing tool called Programmer , the collection features hundreds of images of Portland's "Hooverville" settlement and Oregon migrant families snapped by legendary photojournalist Dorothea Lange.
The photos, commissioned by the Roosevelt administration in 1935 to gain public support for an initiative to resettle poor farmers displaced during by the Depression, have been stored in the Library of Congress for more than 50 years.
(As you'll see in the photos above, anti-migrant-worker xenophobia was big and ugly in Portland in the 1930s.)
Yale University's Photogrammer tool. photogrammar.yale.edu The database, which gives a gritty glimpse of life in rural areas from 1935 to 1945, allows users to zoom into counties or to search by photographers, tags and keywords.
But here we are, yapping about the database, instead of letting you use it. Give it try.
